div.p: A cleare forme of Catechising, before the giving of the Sacrament of the Lords Supper.
To this are subjoined two compends of the Catechisme, fit for little Children.

q.p: This is life eternall, to know thee the onely true GOD, and Iesus Christ whom thou hast sent.

div.p: By M. Zacharie Boyd, Preacher of Gods Word at Glasgow.
Printed at Glasgow by George Anderson, 1639.

q.p: Quòd Lex operum minando imperat, Lex Fidei credendo impetrat.

div.head: TO THE READER,
div.p: I Have studied to make all the answers short in these three Catechismes, for the helpe of thy memorie: First to know, and then to doe, is perfect Christianitie.

div.head: TO The most Religious, and Noble Ladie, the Countesse of Argyle, &c.
div.p: THis world is full of people, whose religion is compounded like the TURKISH, in part CHRISTIAN, in part IEVV, in part WORLDLING, in part ATHEIST, in part as A grippa, almost Christians: Only these are happie, who according to the Apostle his wish, Act. 26 29. are altogether Christians.

A time of tryall will come, which shall discerne almost from altogether: Happie shall these professours bee, to whom the Lord shall say, Luke 22 28. Yee are these which have continued with me in my temptations; and I appoint unto you a kingdome,
vers. 29. as my Father hath appointed unto me,
vers. 30. that yee may eate and drink at my table in my kingdome; of all honours this shall be found the greatest.

GOD, Madame, hath highly honoured your La. both with grace and place: As for grace, yee may without flatterie, with S. Iohns Lady, be called the ELECT LADY:2 Iohn 1 As for place, Yee both by birth and marriage are high, but highest in this, that your La. art humble.

I will not heere enter into a large discourse, concerning the Noble and Potent Earle your La. Husband, whose vertues have most Oriently shined in our generall Assembly, which his Lordship did much honour with his presence, and help with his counsell.

That which the Apostle did require for the house of Onesiphorus, that I most heartily wish to his Lordship, to your La. and to all your noble Line and Familie,2 Tim. 1.18. that the Lord grant that yee may finde mercy of the Lord in that day.
Let it please your La. graciously to accept of this little labour, and to honour it with your favour, it shall bee but an EARNEST of more, if I live, and if God permit.

closer.signed: Your Ladiships in all humble duety and observance M. ZACHARY BOYD

list.item: 5. Of the dueties which man owe to God for his Redemption.
6. Of the Sacraments which are the seales of the Covenant betweene God and man.

div.head: 1. SUNDAY.

p.hi: Question.
WHat is God?
Answere.

div.p: An infinite Essence, that hath his being from himself, and is the fountaine of all being.
Q What things are to bee considered in God?
A. The essence and the persons.
Q. What sayest thou of his Essence?
A. It is spirituall, simple, incomprensible, unchangeable.
Q. What difference is betweene the essence of God and the person?
A. The essence is the Divine substance, which is commoun to the three persons; the person is a subsistence in the Divine nature.
Q. How many Gods be there?
A. Only one God.
Q. How many persons are they in the Godhead?
A. Three, the Father, Son, and holy Ghost.

div.head: THE SECOND SUNDAY.

p.hi: ARE not these three persons divided one from another, so that it may be said, here is the Father, and there is the Son?

div.p: A. No, not.
Q. How then?
A. The persons of the Trinitie are diverse one from another, but not separate.
Q. How can that bee?
A. The Father in an unspeakable manner is in the Son, and the Son in the Father, and the holy Spirit in them both.
Q. How are the persons distinguished one from another?
A. By their inward properties, & order of their outward working.
Q. How are they distinguished by their inward properties?
A. By the works which they work within themselves.
Q. What sorts of workes are these which are wrought with in the Trinitie?
A. They are not commoun to all the three persons, but every person hath his owne particular work proper to himself.

div.head: The third Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat is that propertie of the Father, that is not common to the Son, and holy Ghost?

div.p: A. In that he hath begotten the Son from all eternitie, of the same substance with himselfe.
Q. What is that speciall propertie of the Son?
A. That in the unitie of essence he hath from all eternitie beene begotten of the substance of the Father.
Q. What is the propertie of the Holy Ghost?
A. He inseparably proceeds from the Father and the Son.
Q. Is this a reall distinction which is betweene the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost?
A. It is, but we can not be capable of the same.

Q. I have heard how the three persons are distinguished one from
another in their inward properties; now tell me how they are distinguished by their outward working.
A. In that the Father is the Creator of all things, the Son the Redeemer, the holy Ghost our Sanctifier.

div.head: The fourth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. ARE not the outward works of all the persons common to every person of the Trinitie?

div.p: A. They are common indeed.
Q. How are they distinguished?
A. In respect of the order of their working.
Q. Let me heare of the distinct order of their working.
A. The Father hath created us, the Son hath redeemed us, the holy Ghost sanctifieth us.
Q. Wherefore is the Father particularly called our Creator?
A. Because our creation proceeds from the father first in order.
Q. Wherefore is the Sonne called our Redeemer?
A. Because our redemption was performed by the Son.
Q. Wherefore is the holy Ghost called our Sanctifier?
A. Because our sanctification is immediatly wrought by the holy Ghost.
Q. Thy meaning is that in every one of those outward workings, all the three persons concurre together?
A. I understand so.
Q. Esteemest thou that the Father is greater then the Sonne, and holy Ghost?
A. They are equall in dignitie, power, and Majestie.
Q. How then differ they?
A. They differ in number, and in order.
Q. What sayest thou of the Father?
A. He is first, not in dignitie, but in order.
Q. What sayest thou of the Son?
A. Hee is second, not in dignitie, but in order.
Q. What sayest thou of the holy Ghost?
A. He is the third, not in dignitie, but in order.
Q. What sayest thou of the three persons of the Trinitie?
A. These three are the one eternall God, blessed for ever.

div.head: The fifth Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat is it to create a thing?
A. To create properly is to make something of nothing.
Q. How hath God made all things of nothing?
A. By his infinite power.
Q. How governeth Hee all things that hee hath made?
A. By his infinite wisdome.
Q. Whereof was man made?
A. Of the dust of the earth.
Q. What learnest thou thereby?
A. I learne to be humble.
Q. Is there nothing in man but dust?
A. There is a living soule.
Q. How was man made at the first?
A. According to Gods image.
Q. What is that image of God, according to which man was made?
A. Perfect holinesse and righteousnesse.
Q. What other thing is to be considered in that image of God?
A. The likenesse and resemblance of man with God, was also in respect of that rule and authoritie given unto him by God over all the creatures.

div.head: The sixth Sunday.
div.p: Q. DID man keepe that image of God?
A. No, not.
Q. How lost he it?
A. By sinning against God.
Q. What was his sin against God?
A. He did eat of the forbidden tree.
Q. What other sin had he?
A. Pride, and unbeliefe.
Q. What was his pride?
A. He would be equall unto God.
Q. What was his unbeliefe?
A. He believed Sathan, and not God.
Q. What said Sathan unto him that he beleeved?
A. He said he should be equall unto God himselfe.
Q. What said God unto him?
A. He said that hee should die the death.
Q. Who were the instruments of mans fall?
A. The Divel, the Serpent, and the Woman.
Q. How did these three deceive the man?
A. The Divel entered a lying spirit into the Serpent, and by the Serpent seduced the woman, who entised her husband to eate of the tree.
Q. What deserved they for such eating?
A. Death and eternall Condamnation.
Q. But how could God in justice for so light a sin destroy all mankinde?
A. The sin was not light, because it was done against an infinit Majestie.
Q. What hath followed upon this sin?
A. All men since that fall are borne in sinne, and conceived in iniquitie.

div.head: The seventh Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat is sin?

div.p: A. The transgression of Gods Law.

p.hi: Q. How many sortes of sinne bee there?

div.p: A. Two: originall sin, and actuall sin.

p.hi: Q. What callest thou original sin?

div.p: A. That corruption wherein all mankinde is conceived; and born, since the fall of Adam.

p.hi: Q. What hath this sinne done to man?

div.p: A. It hath defiled all the faculties of his soule.

p.hi: Q. What hath it done to his minde and understanding?

div.p: A. It hath so blindfolded it, that the wisdome of God seemeth folie to man.
Q. What hath it done to his will?
A. It hath made it perverse and froward against the will of God.
Q. What hath it done to his affections?
A. It hath set them altogether upon corruption, and uncleanes.
Q. This then is thy meaning, that originall sin, like a leprosie, hath desiled the whole man?
A. It is even so.

div.head: The eight Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat callest thou actuall sinne?
A. Every omission of our duety, and commission of that which is against the law of God.

p.hi: Q. In how many wayes sin we?

div.p: A. In three wayes especially in thought, in word, and in work.

p.hi: Q. Can a lightword be sinne?

div.p: A. For every ydle word we shall give account.
Q. But is not our thought free?
A. No, not.
Q. How knowest thou that an evill thought is sin?
A. Christ hath said, that to lust after another mans wife, is to commit adulterie in the heart.

p.hi: Q. How differeth originall sinne from actuall sinne?

div.p: A. As the tree from the fruite, or as the root from the branches.

p.hi: Q. Thy meaning, is that originall sinne, is the root from whence spring all our actuall sins?

div.p: A. I understand so.

div.head: The ninth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. ARE all men sinners?

div.p: A. Yea, verily.

p.hi: Q. Is it not said, that these that are borne of God sin not?

div.p: A. Sin reigneth not in their mortall bodies.

p.hi: Q. When is sin said to reigne in a man?

div.p: A. When hee so taketh delight in his sins, that hee careth not in any wife for the offending of God.

p.hi: Q. Doe the godly sin with such a delight?

div.p: A. No, not; they doe the evill they would not.

p.hi: Q. How is that done?

div.p: A. The flesh coveteth against the Spirit.

p.hi: Q. What understandest thou by the coveting flesh?

div.p: A. That remainder of naturall corruption, which as yet is unmortified in the godly.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore callest thou these rests of corruption in the faithfull, after the name of flesh?

div.p:
A. Because through the flesh, or through carnall generation, the
filthinesse of sin is conveyed unto the whole man.

p.hi: Q. What other reason may bee given.?

div.p: A. Because the flesh or body is the instrument to execute the lustes of our naturall concupiscence.

p.hi: Q. What understandest thou by the Spirit against whom our corruptions covet?

div.p: A. By the Spirit I understand the holy Spirit, and his working, whereby our naturall corruptions are subdued.

p.hi: Q. What deserve our sinnes at Gods hand?

div.p: A. Death.

p.hi: Q. How many sortes of death be there?

div.p: A. Two, the death of the body, and the death of the soule.

div.head: The tenth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WEE have heard first of GOD, secondly of mens creation, thirdly of his fall into sin, which deserveth death, now it followeth that thou declare who is mans Saviour?

div.p: A. Jesus Christ.

p.hi: Q. Who is Iesus Christ?

div.p: A. The Sonne of GOD conceaved miraculously by the holy Ghost, in the wombe of a Virgine.

p.hi: Q. Beleevest thou that he is that promised seede of the woman?

div.p: A. I do so with my heart.

p.hi: Q. Whether was he man onely, or both God and man?

div.p: A. He was both GOD and man, in one person.

p.hi: Q What needed the Saviour of man, to be man?

div.p: A. That hee might die for our sinnes.

p.hi: Q. What other reason be there?

div.p: A. Seeing it was man that had sinned, the justice of GOD required that a man should suffer for the sin of man.
Q. Wherefore needed our Saviour to be GOD▪
A. That he might beare that infinite wrath of GOD, and at last overcome death.
Q. What other reason hast thou?
A. That his death might be of ane infinite merite.
Q. Thou thinkest then that none but hee who was also GOD, could overcome death, and by his death make a full satisfaction to GODS justice?
A. I beleeue so.

div.head: The eleventh Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHerefore was Hee called Jesus?
A. Because Hee came to save his people from their sins.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore callest thou Him CHRIST?

div.p: A. Because hee was anointed with the spirituall oyle of grace, and that without measure.

p.hi: Q. Whereunto was he anointed?

div.p: A. Unto three spirituall offices.

p.hi: Q. What were his offices?

div.p: A. He was a King, a Prophet, and a Priest.

p.hi: Q. What needed our Saviour to be a King?

div.p: A. For to rule and defend us against our enemies.

p.hi: Q. Who are our chiefest enemies?

div.p: A. The Divel, the world, and the corruptions of our own flesh.

p.hi: Q. What needed him to bee a Prophet?

div.p: A. For to teach us by his word the way of salvation.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore was he a Priest?

div.p: A. For to offer up sacrifice for us.

p.hi: Q. What sacrifice offered he up?

div.p: A. Hee offered up himselfe once for all.

p.hi: Q. What sort of death died he for us?

div.p: A. A cursed death▪ upon á tree.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore died Hee such a cursed death?

div.p: A. That hee might deliver us from the curse of God.

p.hi: Q. Is there such a power in Christs death?

div.p: A. Yea verily.

p.hi: Q. Wherefra cometh this power?

div.p: A. From the dignitie of his person.

p.hi: Q. Esteemest thou that the infinite merite of Christs death is from the dignitie of his person?

div.p: A. I understand so.

div.head: Of the dueties which man owe to GOD for his Redemption.
The twelfth Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat owe we to God for so great a Salvation?
A. We owe to him service.

p.hi: Q. How many parts are they of God's service?

div.p: A. Foure, faith, obedience, prayer, and thanks.

p.hi: Q. What is faith?

div.p: A. It is an assured knowledge of Gods mercy in Christ, particularly apprehended by these whom God hath elected to salvation.

p.hi: Q. Is not Sathan said to beleeve?

div.p: A. He hath knowledge, but not that assurance which is the life of faith.

p.hi: Q. Thou understandest that Sathan knoweth that God is infinite in mercy, but that he hath no assurance of any mercy for himselfe?

div.p: A. I understand so.

p.hi: Q. Who worketh this true faith in our hearts?

div.p: A. The holy spirit.

p.hi: Q. By what meanes worketh he the same?

div.p: A. By the preaching of the Word.

p.hi: Q. Is our faith perfect?

div.p: A. As long as we are here we must pray God to increase our faith.

div.head: The thirteenth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. BY what meanes is our faith strengthned?

div.p: A. By the continued hearing of the word, by earnest prayer, by receiving of the Sacraments, and by a good life.

p.hi: Q Wherefore are we said to be justified by faith?

div.p: A. Because by faith we apprehend Christ, and all his merites, whereby wee appeare just in Gods presence.
Q. Is not man justified by his good works?
A. Before men he may be, but not before God.
Q. Wherefore not before God?
A. Because God hath denounced a curse against him that fulfilleth not perfectly the whole law.
Q. Can not a man perfectly fulfill the law of God?
A. No, not.
Q. How provest thou that?
A. Because there is no man but he sinneth, and sin is the transgression of the law.
Q. Thou beleevest that it is Christ onely, who by his works and sufferings hath made full satisfaction for all the faithfull?
A. I beleeve so.

div.head: The fourteenth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. MAY not a man bee saved without Faith?

div.p: A. There is no salvation without faith.

p.hi: Q. Give a reason wherefore not.

div.p: A. Because without faith it is impossible to please God.
Q. Where is the summe of our faith to be found?
A. In the Creede.
Q. Into how many parts may the Creede be divided?
A. Into four parts.
Q. What doeth the first part containe?
A. Concerning God the Father, and our Creation.
Q. What doeth the second part containe?
A. Concerning God the Son, and our Redemption.
Q. What is in the third part?
A. Concerning the holy Ghost and our sanctification.

p.hi: Q What doth the fourth and last part of our Creed containe?

div.p: A. Concerning Gods Church, and his gifts bestowed upon her.

div.head: The fifeteenth Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat have we in the Creed concerning God the Father?
A. Three things, his name, his attribute, his work.

p.hi: Q. What is his name?

div.p: A. He is called Father.

p.hi: Q. Whose Father is he?

div.p: A. He is Christs and ours.

p.hi: Q. How is he Christs Father?

div.p: A. By generation he hath begotten him from all eternitie.

p.hi: Q. How is he our Father?

div.p: A. By adoption especially.

p.hi: Q. What callest thou Adoption?

div.p: A. That is, God of his free mercy and grace hath chosen us to be his heires in Christ.
Q. What is the Fathers attribute?
A. Almighty.
Q. What understandest thou by the word Almightie?
A. That he hath all power to doe what he pleaseth in Heaven, and in earth.
Q. What is his worke?
A. Hee hath created the Heavens and the earth, that is, by his infinite power hath made them all of nothing.
Q. What doth he now to these things which he hath created?
A. Hee still upholdeth and governeth them by his providence.

div.head: The sixteenth Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat have wee in the Creede concerning God the Sonne.
A. Four chief things.

p.hi: Q. What bee these?

div.p: A. His titles, his incarnation, his passion, and his exaltation.
Q. What are his titles?
A. They are foure, to wit, Jesus, Christ, his Son, our Lord.
Q. What callest thou his incarnation?
A. He was incarnate when the word was made flesh.
Q. How many things hast thou to consider concerning his incarnation?
A. Three chiefly, the personall union, the sanctification of that masse, whereof Christs body was made, and the efficient cause that wrought that work.
Q. Wherein did that personall union consist?
A. In the joining of the divine and humane nature together in one person.

div.head: The seventeenth Sunday.
div.p: Q. HOw many natures are they in Christ Iesus?
A. Two: the Divine and the humane nature, Christ God and man.
Q. Is not Christ God and man two persons?
A. No, not; but the two natures are joined into one person.
Q. How was this great worke wrought?
A. By the unspeakable power of the holy Ghost.
Q. What sayest thou of Christs birth?
A. Hee was borne of the Virgine Mary.
Q. Wherefore behooved it him to be borne of a Virgine?
A. That hee might be conceived without sin, and so might bee a perfect Saviour.
Q. Hast thou no other reason?

A. It was so foretold, that the
seede of the woman; and not of the man, should tread down the head of the Serpent.

div.head: The eighteene Sunday.
div.p: Q. I have heard of Christ's titles, and of his incarnation, now let me heare what befell unto him after his birth?
A. He was first humbled, and thereafter exalted.
Q. How many parts are they of his humiliation?
A. Foure.
Q. What was the first?
A. He suffered many sorrowes.
Q. What was the second?
A. He died on the cursed tree of the crosse.
Q. What was the third?
A. He was buried.
Q. What was the fourth?
A. He descend unto hell.
Q. What sorrowes suffered he?

A. Hunger and thirst and wearynesse,
revilings, scornings, and fearfull persecution.
Q. Wherefore dyed he?
A. For our sins.
Q. Might not satisfaction be made without death?
A. No, not,

p.hi: Q. What is the reason?

div.p: A. Because the wages of sinne is death.

p.hi: Q. What sort of death dyed he?

div.p: A. The cursed death of the Crosse.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore was the death of the Crosse more cursed then any other death?

div.p: Q. Because GOD had said, cursed be that hangeth on a tree.

p.hi: A. Wherefore was that hanging called cursed?

div.p: A. Not for the punishment it selfe, but for sinne the cause of that punishment.
Q. For what other reasons was that death called cursed?
A. There be two other reasons.
Q. What is the first reason?
A. It was called cursed, because of the excessive paine and shame that was in that death.
Q. What is the other reason?
A. Because by that death God in manner of a Prophesie did designe Christ, who by dying on a tree should redeeme us from the curse of the law.
Q. What needed Christ to be buried?
A. For to assure the world of his death.
Q. What is that to say, that he descended into hell?
A. That is, he suffered in his soule unspeakeable torments for our sinnes.
Q. When chiefly suffered he these paines?
A. When he cryed, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?

div.head: The ninteene Sunday.

p.hi: Q. FRom Christs humiliation let us come to his exaltation: How many degrees are they of his exaltation?

div.p: A. Three; first his resurrection, Secondly his ascension; Thirdly his sitting at the right hand of God the Father.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore did Christ rise againe from the dead?

div.p: A. For to show that he had overcome death.

p.hi: Q. What other reason is there of his resurrection?

div.p: A. Hee being God and man in one person, could not be holden of death.
Q. For what other cause arose He?
A. As He died for our sinnes, so Hee arose for our righteousnesse.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore was Christ said to arise for our righteousnesse?

div.p: A. Because by his resurrection he did evidently declare, that he had by his death purchased righteousnesse to our Soules.
Q. What comfort hast thou of Christs resurrection?
A. That my dead body and all the dead bodies of the faithfull shall likewise arise at the last day.
Q. What ground hast thou of that comfort?
A. Because Christ who is risen is the head, and wee who are the members must follow the head.

div.head: The twentie Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WEE have heard of Christs resurrection, the first degree of his exaltation; what is the second?

div.p: A. His ascension into heaven.
Q. By what power was that done?
A. By the might and power of his Godhead.
Q. Is not his body on earth any more?
A. No, not.
Q. But he hath said, that he will be with his Church unto the end of the world?
A. That is to be understood of the presence of his Spirit.
Q. But how can his manhood be seperate from his Godhead?
A. They are no more seperate then the sun and his beames.

p.hi: Q. Make that more cleare?

div.p: A. The body of the sun is only in the heavens, but his beames do descend unto the Earth; So Christ man is onely in the heavens, but his Godhead filleth both heaven and Earth.

p.hi: Q. What comfort hast thou of Christs ascension?

div.p: A. Hee is gone up for to prepare a roome for his Saints.

p.hi: Q. How knowest thou that?

div.p: A. Hee hath said, I goe to prepare a place for you, and I will come againe, and receive you unto my self, that where I am, there yee may bee also, Iohn 14.3.

div.head: The twentie one Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHAT is the third degree of his exaltation?

div.p: A. He sitteth at the right hand of God the Father.

p.hi: Q. Hath God a right hand or a left?

div.p: A. No, not; for GOD is a Spirit.
Q. What then, is that to sit at Gods right hand?

A. It is a forme of speach borrowed from Princes, whose custome is to place at their right
hand these whom they honour above others.
Q. What then is the meaning of these words, that Christ sitteth at the right hand of God?
A. That hee is in unspeakable dignitie and authoritie, having absolute power over all the creatures.
Q. What is the Lord now doeing for us at the right hand of his Father?
A. Hee is interceeding for us, that is, making request and intreatie in our behalf.

div.head: The twentie two Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat is the manner of CHRISTS intercession, while he is now in the Heavens?
A. He ascended up into heaven, to appeare in the sight of God for us, Hebr. 9.24.

p.hi: Q. How is that done?

div.p: A. By presenting his person and his passion before the face of God.

p.hi: Q. Hovv then doth hee request for us?

div.p: A. By willing and desiring that his Father would accept his merits in our behalfe.

p.hi: Q. Shall the Lords body for ever remaine in the heavens?

div.p: A. No, not, at the last day he shall come downe to judge the quicke and the dead.

p.hi: Q. Hovv shall the judge come dovvne?

div.p: A. He shall descend with a shout with the voice of the Archangel, and with the Trumpet of God in unspeakable glory.
Q. What honour shall the godly have that day?
A. They shall all sit downe upon Thrones at Christs right hand.

p.hi: Q. What shall they doe upon these Thrones?

div.p: A. They shall judge the world, 1 Cor. 6.2.

p.hi: Q. But shall not Christ himselfe that day be the onely judge?

div.p: A. Hee shall bee so, but his Saints shall sit as assessours, for to approve his judgement.

p.hi: Q. Where shall the wicked then be?

div.p: A. At Christs left hand.

p.hi: Q. What understand yee by his left hand?

div.p: A. As to bee at his right hand is understood to bee in dignitie, so to bee at his left, is understood to be in shame and ignominie.

p.hi: Q. What shall the judge say unto the godly at his right hand?

div.p: A. Come yee blessed of my Father, and receive a kingdome.

p.hi: Q. What shall he say to the wicked at his left hand?

div.p: A. Depart from me to hell fire, with the Divel and his angels.

div.head: The twentie third Sunday.
div.p: Q. WEE have heard of the first two parts of the Creede to wit, of the Father and of the Sonne: what is contained in the third part?
A. That which concerneth the holy Ghost, the third person of the Trinitie.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore callest thou him holy?

div.p: A. Both for his nature and his office.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore is he called holy for his nature?

div.p: A. Because hee is holy in himself, yea, holinesse it self.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore is he called holy for his office?

div.p: A. Because by his operation he maketh all the faithfull holy.
Q. What be the chiefe fruits of the holy Ghost?
A. Faith, love, joy, gentlenesse, meeknesse, temperance, peace and patience &c.

div.head: The twentie foure Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat is contained in the fourth part of the Creed?

div.p: A. That which concerneth the Church.
Q. What is the Churche?
A. A companie of these whom GOD by his Spirit hath sanctified.

p.hi: Q. What are the qualities of the Church?

div.p: A. It is holy and catholicke.
Q. Wherefore callest thou it holy?
A. Because Gods children on earth are holy in part, and in heaven are perfectly holy.
Q. Wherefore callest thou it Catholicke?
Q. Because it is universall, and reacheth unto all nations, to all times, sexe and age.

p.hi: Q. How many parts hath the Catholicke Church?

div.p: A. Two, the Church triumphant in heaven, and the Church militant on earth.

p.hi: Q. Whom callest thou the Church triumphant?

div.p: A. These who in the spirituall warfare have overcome the Devill, the World, and the flesh.

p.hi: Q. Whom callest thou the Church militant?

div.p: A. These who are yet on earth fighting against the enemies of their salvation.

div.head: The twentie five Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat are the chief prerogatives of the kirk?
A. These four, the communion of Saints, the forgivenesse of sins, the resurrection of the body, and life everlasting.

p.hi: Q. What is that communion of Saints?

div.p: A. It is that love and fellowship which the children of God have with Christ, and among themselves.

p.hi: Q. Who are these Saints?

div.p: A. The Faithfull on the earth and the Souls of the Faithfull now in heaven.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore are they called Saints?

div.p: A. Because they have beene sanctified by the holy Spirit.

p.hi: Q. What is the second benefite belonging to the Church?

div.p: A. The remission of sins.
Q. What call ye the remission of sins?
A. A free pardon, and forgivenesse of all our faults.
Q. Who hath procured this?
A. Christ Jesus by his death upon the crosse.

div.head: The twentie sixth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the third benefite belonging to the church?

div.p: A. The resurrection of the body.
Q. What is the cause of the resurrection of the faithfull?
A. The resurrection of Christ.
Q. Is Christs resurrection the proper cause which effecteth the resurrection of the faithfull?
A. It is the true cause indeed.

p.hi: Q. Give me the reason?

div.p: A. Christ is the head, and the godly are his members, which must follow their head.

p.hi: Q. What then shall bee the cause of the resurrection of the Wicked? Shall they not rise by the vertue of CHRISTS resurrection?

div.p: A. No, not.

p.hi: Q. By what power then shall they rise?

div.p: A. By the power of Christs justice, constraining them to come out of their graves.

p.hi: Q. What is the last benefite that GOD shall bestow upon His Church?

div.p: A. Life everlasting.

p.hi: Q. What a life shall that be?

div.p: A. A life perfectly happy in the heavens.
Q. What things shall wee enjoy in the heavens?
A. Fulnesse of joy, and pleasures for evermore.

div.head: The twentie seven Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WE have heard of the first part of Gods service, which is to believe in God, Now let me hear what is the second part of Gods service.

div.p: A. It is to obey God.

p.hi: Q. Where learne we what obedience we owe to God?

div.p: A. In Gods law, whereof the summe is the ten commandments.

p.hi: Q. How are the ten commandements divided?

div.p: A. Into two tables.

p.hi: Q. How many commandements are there in the first table?

div.p: A. The first foure.

p.hi: Q. How many in the second?

div.p: A. The last six.

p.hi: Q. What is the summe of the first foure?

div.p: A. Our whole duetie towards our GOD.

p.hi: Q. What is the summe of the last six?

div.p: A. Our whole duetie towards our neighbour.

div.head: The twentie eight Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat is the first Commandement?
A. Thou shalt have no other Gods before my face,

p.hi: Q. What is there forbidden?

div.p: A. All atheisme, and giving of Gods honour to any thing beside God.

p.hi: Q. What is there commanded?

div.p: A. The worship of the true God.

p.hi: Q. What is the second commandement?

div.p: A. Thou shalt not make to thy self any graven image, &c.
Q. What is there forbidden?
A. That we represent not God by any outward shape or figure.
Q Wherefore that?
A. Because God is invisible, and can not by any image be represented truely.
Q. What difference is between the first commandement and the second?
A. In the first, the inward worship of GOD is commanded, in the second, the outward forme which is fittest for the worshipping of GOD is enjoyned.
Q. What is the third commandement?
A. Thou shalt not take the name of the LORD thy GOD in vaine.

p.hi: Q. What is heere forbidden?

div.p: A. All blasphemies, all unreverent speakings, or thinking of God, or doing of his worship otherwise then he hath ordained.

p.hi: Q. What is heere commanded?

div.p: A. That we both thinke and speake with all reverence of his titles, words and workes.

div.head: The twentie ninth Sunday.
div.p: Q. GOE to the fourth commandement?
A. Remember thou keepe holy the Sabboth day, &c.
Q. What is heere commanded?
A. That we consecrate the seventh day unto his service.
Q. What is forbidden?
A. All worldly businesse, also all the words and thoughts which concerne the affaires of the earth.
Q. May we neither thinke nor speake of things concerning the earth on the Sabboth day?
A. No, not. As in that day we are forbidden to speake our own wordes; So also to thinke our owne thoughts.

p.hi: Q. What signifieth the word Sabboth?

div.p: A. Sabboth day, that is a day of rest, or of ceasing, from worke.

p.hi: Q. What callest thou to sanctifie the Sabboth?

div.p: A. It is to seperate it from common workes, such as pertaine to this naturall life, and consecrate it to God and to holy workes, such as concerne the spirituall life.

p.hi: Q. What are the workes of the Sabboth day?

div.p: A. To preach the word, to heare it, to meditate, to confer, to visite the sicke, to give almes to the poore.

p.hi: Q. What time must be observed in the observation of the Sabboth?

div.p: A. From evening to evening, said the Lord, you shalt celebrate your Sabboth. Levit. 23.32.

div.head: The thirtie Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat is the fifth commandement?
A. Honour thy Father and thy mother, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is heere commanded?

div.p: A. That all inferiours reverence both in heart and outward gesture their Superiours, and that also Superiours, do their duty to their inferiours.
Q. What is heere forbidden?
A. All contemning of superiours, and all disdaining of inferiours, in thought, word, or worke.

p.hi: Q. What is the sixt commandement?

div.p: A. Thou shalt not murder.

p.hi: Q. What is heere forbidden?

div.p: A. To hurt any way our neighbours person.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is heere commanded?

div.p: A. To do what we can for the preservation of the life of our neighbour.

p.hi: Q▪ VVhat is the seventh commandement?

div.p: A. Thou shalt not commit adulterie.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is heere forbidden?

div.p: A. All sortes of filthinesse, either in thought, word, or work.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is heere commanded?

div.p: A. That we keepe our vessels cleane in sanctification and honour.

div.head: The thirtie one Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the eight commandement?

div.p: A. Thou shalt not steale.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is forbidden there?

div.p: A. To greedily cover, reave, seeke, or take by fraud that which is not our owne, or to spend our owne lavishly.
Q. VVhat is there commanded?

A. That we carefully keepe our neighbours goods, as though they were out owne, and also to
manage well that which GOD hath given us.
Q. What is the ninth commandement?
A. Thou shalt not beare false witnesse.

p.hi: Q. What is heere commanded?

div.p: A. To love the trueth, and to maintaine it.

p.hi: Q. What is the tenth commandement?

div.p: A. Thou shalt not cover thy neighbours house, nor his wife, &c.

p.hi: Q. What is the summe thereof?

div.p: A. That we keepe our hearts from the least inclination to sinne.

p.hi: Q What is heere forbidden, that was not forbidden in the other commandements?

div.p:
A. In the other commandements, the stronger evill desires which are fostred with consent, are forbidden; but in this commandement, the least evill thoughts is disallowed,
though as soone as it in our heart, we abhorre it.

p.hi: Q. Thou willest then that in the other commandements, these evill thoughts are forbidden which are entertained and made welcome, but that in the tenth commandement, the least motion of the heart to sinne is forbidden, though it want a full consent or likeing?

div.p: A. I understand so.
Q. What is the summe of the whole law?
A. That we love the Lord our God with all our heart, with all our soule, and with our whole strength, and that wee love our neighbour as our self.

div.head: The thirtie two Sunday.
div.p: Q. WEE have heard of faith and obedience the two first parts of Gods service: now let us heare what is the third part of Gods service?
A. To pray to God.

p.hi: Q. What is prayer?

div.p: A. A putting up of our requests to God, in the name of his Sonne.

p.hi: Q. For whose sake must we seeke from God, the things we stand in neede of?

div.p: A. For Christ Jesus his sake.

p.hi: Q. May we not desire the Saints of heaven to pray for us?

div.p: A. There is but one Mediator Jesus Christ.
Q. Doe wee know how to pray as we should?
A. Not, but the Spirit of God who helpeth our infirmities, putteth good motions into our minde, and good words into our mouth.
Q. What is the best rule of prayer which we have?
A. That patterne of Christs, Our Father which art in Heaven, hallowed be thy Name, &c.
Q. How many parts are they in the Lords prayer?
A. Three; the preface, the petitions, and the conclusion.

div.head: The thirtie three Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat are the wordes of the preface?
A. Our Father which art in Heaven.

p.hi: Q. What good learne we of these wordes?

div.p: A. To come with boldnesse to our GOD, because Hee is our Father, and also with great respect, because hee is our heavenly Father.

p.hi: Q. How many petitions are in the Lords prayer?

div.p: A. Six.
Q. How divide you these six petitions?
A. The first three concerne GODS owne glory; the last three concerne our selves, and our neighbour.
Q. What is the first petition?
A. Hallowed bee thy Name.
Q. What is the meaning of these wordes?
A. That GOD may be knowne to be a holy GOD, and so may bee reverenced and worshipped by all his creatures.
Q. What is the second petition?
A. Thy kingdome come.
Q. What is the meaning thereof?
A. That Christ may both inwardly in our hearts, and outwardly among men rule and governe, untill hee put all his enemies under his feete.
Q. What is the third petition?
A. Thy will bee done in earth, as it is in Heaven.
Q. What is the meaning thereof?
A. That GOD bee obeyed as perfectly by his Saints on Earth, as by the Saints and Angels of Heaven.

div.head: The thirtie fourth Sunday.

p.hi: Q. I have heard of the first three petitions which concerne God, now tell me what is the first of the three petitions which concerne our selves and our neighbour?

div.p: A. The first of those three, is, Give us this day our dayly bread.
Q. What is the meaning thereof?

A. That GOD would give unto us the things of this world, as meat, drink, cloathing, honour, children, or any other worldly thing, so far as hee thinketh it expedient for his owne glory, and for our well.
Q▪ What is the second petition?
A. Forgive us our trespasses, as wee forgive them that trespasse against us.

p.hi: Q. What is the meaning thereof?

div.p: A. That GOD in his mercy would most freely pardon our sins.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore is this subjoyned as we forgive these that trespasse against us?

div.p: A. To teach us to be mercifull to these that offend us.

p.hi: Q. What is the last petition?

div.p: A. And leade us not into temptation, but deliver us from evill.
Q. What is the meaning thereof?
A. That GOD deliver us from the snaires of the Devil, of the world, and of our owne corruptions, and from all other dangers whatsoever.
Q. What is the conclusion of that most perfect prayer?
A. For thine is the Kingdome, the Power, and the Glory, for ever.

p.hi: Q. How many things are to be considered in these words?

div.p: A. Foure; first that God is a King; Secondly, that he is powerfull, Thirdly, that hee is glorious; Fourthly, that hee is eternall.

div.head: The thirtie five Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHat is the fourth and last part of GODS service?
A. To give God thanks for all his benefites.

p.hi: Q. What thankes requireth God of us?

div.p: A. That we set foorth his glory with heart, tongue, and hand.
Q. How thank we GOD with our hearts?
A. When wee think honourably of him, and acknowledge his goodnesse.

p.hi: Q. How thank we him with our tongues?

div.p: A. When our tongues are instruments of setting foorth his glory in godly words.

p.hi: Q. How thank we God with our handes?

div.p: A. When the actions of our life are so holy, that these who see them, are moved to praise our heavenly Father.
Q. What is the summe of the whole Covenant betweene GOD and man?
A. That GOD shall bee a friend to man, and that man shall serve GOD, by believing in him, by obeying him, by praying unto him, and by giving him thanks.

p.hi: Q. Thou understandest heere the Covenant betweene God and man, is a mutuall promise betweene God and man, to wit, that God shall be a friend to man, and man shall be a faithfull servant unto God?

div.p: A. I understand so.

div.head: The thirtie six Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat callest thou a Covenant?

div.p: A. A league or agreement betweene two or more parties.

p.hi: Q. What is the Covenant of God and man?

div.p: A. A league or agreement which God hath made with men for salvation.

p.hi: Q. What other name hath this Covenant in Scriptures?

div.p: A. It is called a Testament.

p.hi: Q. What is properly called a Testament?

div.p: A. That which we commonly call a mans will and appointment, for the bestowing of his goods among his friends▪

p.hi: Q. Wherefore is Gods Covenant called a Testament?

div.p: A. Because it was confirmed and ratified by the death of Christ who made the Covenant, and also because it containeth his last will written down.

p.hi: Q. How many Covenants hath God made with man?

div.p: A. Two, the Covenant of workes, and the Covenant of grace.

p.hi: Q. What callest thou the Covenant of workes?

div.p:
A. It was a league which God made with Adam and all his posteritie,
on condition of their perfect obedience.

p.hi: Q. Did man keepe that Covenant?

div.p: A. No, not.

p.hi: Q. Is he now able to keepe it?

div.p: A. No, not.
Q. Wherefore is it then delivered unto men in the Scriptures?
A. To convince them of sin, that they may seek mercy in Christ.
Q. What callest thou the Covenant of grace?
A. It is an agreement concerning men, to bee freely saved through faith in Christ.
Q. What is the substance of this Covenant?
A. Salvation by faith in Christ.
Q. When, and where was the Covenant of grace made?
A. Incontinent after Adams fall, GOD in Paradise promised, that Christ, the feed of the woman should tread down the head of the Divel, the old Serpent.

p.hi: Q. How many Covenants of grace hath GOD made with man?

div.p: A. Onely one.
Q. In Scriptures I read of an old Testament or Covenant and of a new Testament or Covenant?
A. The same Covenant of grace is either old or new, in diverse respects and circumstances, being one for Substance.
Q. Wherefore callest thou the Covenant of grace, the old Covenant?
A. In regard of the first dispensation of it, by Moses towards the Jewes in diverse rites and ceremonies, which in time like old things vanish away.
Q. Wherefore is it called a new Testament or Covenant?
A. In regard of the dispensation of it by Christ, without such rites and figures, to endure alwayes new and the same unto the end of the world.

div.head: The thirtie seventh Sunday.
div.p: Q. WEE have heard of the first five parts of the Catechisme, First, of God, Secondly, of mans Creation, Thirdly, of his Fall, Fourthly, of his Redemption; Fifthly, of mans dueties to GOD for the same, which is the summe of the Covenant between GOD and man, now let me heare of the seales of that Covenant?
A. The Sacraments are these seales.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore serve these seales?

div.p: A. For the confirmation of our Faith.

p.hi: Q. What neede have we of seales unto Gods promises, seeing God cannot lie.

div.p: A. Because our faith is weake, it hath neede to be strengthned.

p.hi: Q. What is a Sacrament?

div.p: A. It is an outward seale appointed by God, for to certifie us of our Salvation in Christ.

p.hi: Q. How many Sacraments had the Jewes under the law?

div.p: A. Two; Circumcision and the Paschall Lambe.

p.hi: Q. What was the outward seale in Circumcision?

div.p: A. The cutting away of the foreskine.

p.hi: Q. What did that represent and seale?

div.p: A. The cutting away of the Superfluitie of Sin.

p.hi: Q. What was the outward signe and seale of the Sacrament of the lambe?

div.p: A. The lambe was first killed, after it was eaten.

p.hi: Q. What did all that represent and seale?

div.p: A. That Christ was killed for to be food for our soules.

div.head: The thirtie eight Sunday.

p.hi: Q. HOW many Sacraments are they under the Gospell?

div.p: A. Two, Baptisme and the Lords Supper.
Q. What is Baptisme?
A. A seale of our entrance into the Church.
Q. What is the visible signe in Baptisme?
A. The element of water with the outward actions, as the sprinkling, washing, dipping into water, abiding under the water, and comming out of the water.

p.hi: Q. What doth the water represent unto us?

div.p: A. The blood of Jesus Christ and his Spirit.
Q. What are the speciall graces sealed up untous, while wee are baptized?
A. Our Justification and Sanctification.

p.hi: Q. What outward action represents our justification?

div.p: A. As the water washeth away all uncleanesse from the body, so the blood of Christ washeth away all sinnes from our soules, which is our justification.
Q. What outward actions represent our Sanctification?
A. They be cheefly three, first, the dipping of the body, Secondly, the staying under the water, Thirdly the comming out of the water.
Q. What signifieth the dipping of the body?
A. It signifieth the mortification of sinne, or fellowship with Christ in his death.
Q. What signifieth the staying under the water?
A. It signifieth the buriall of sin.

p.hi: Q. What signifieth the comming out of the water?

div.p: A. The resurrection from sin to newnesse of life▪ Rom. 6.3.

p.hi: Q. What is the differences of these two graces Iustification and Sanctification, which are sealed by our Baptisme?

div.p: A. Justification is the absolution of a sinner from the guilt of sinne; Sanctification is an alteration of qualities from evill to good.
Q. Make the matter yet more cleare?
A. Justification consists in remission of sinnes, and imputation of justice for the obedience of Christ; Sanctification is a renovation from our corrupt nature.

p.hi: Q. What other difference is betweene these two.

div.p: A. Justification is perfect in this life, but Sanctification is heere imperfect.
Q. To whom belongs the Sacraments of Baptisme?
A. To all the faithfull, and to their children.
Q. By what reason provest thou that little children should be baptixed?
A. Because they are entered into the Church, and Baptisme is a seale of their entrance into the same.

div.head: The thirtie ninth Sunday.
div.p: Q. WHAT is the Lords Supper?
A. A seale of our spirituall nourishment in the Church.

p.hi: Q. What are the visible signes?

div.p: A. Bread and wine.

p.hi: Q. What other signes are in the Lords Supper?

div.p: A. The outward actions, to wit, the breaking of the bread, and powring out of the wine, and the distributing of the same.

p.hi: Q. What doth the bread in the Sacrament represent?

div.p: A. The blessed body of Christ.

p.hi: Q. What doth the breaking of the bread represent?

div.p: A. The breaking of Christs body and soule with unspeakable torments.

p.hi: Q. What doth the wine signifie?

div.p: A. The blood of Christ.

p.hi: Q. What doth the powring out of the wine signifie?

div.p: A. The powring out of Christs blood.

p.hi: Q. What is the spirituall grace represented and offered unto us, by the elements and actions?

div.p: A. The nourishment of our souls.
Q. Make that more cleare?

A. As the bread eaten feeds the body, and as the wine drunke rejoyceth the heart, so the body and blood of Christ apprehended by a lively faith, like meat strengthneth, and like wine rejoiceth the soule.

div.head: The fourtie Sunday.
div.p: Q. MAY not little children be partakers of the Sacrament of the Supper, as well as of Baptisme?
A. No, not.

p.hi: Q. What is the reason?

div.p: A. Baptisme is a Sacrament of our entrance into the Church, but the Sacrament of the Supper is onely for these that have understanding.

p.hi: Q. How knowest thou that?

div.p: A. Because it is enjoined to all these that partake of the Supper, to try & examine themselves, which infants cannot do.

p.hi: Q. What are the spirituall duties of these that would rightly communicate?

div.p: A. That every man examine himself, and so eate of that bread, and drinke of that cup.

p.hi: Q. Wherein consists that examination?

div.p: A. That a man try himselfe if he hath these three things, faith, love, and repentance.

div.head: The fourtie one Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHAT should he try of his faith?

div.p: A. If he knoweth God, and is in some measure assured that Christ died for him.
Qu What if his faith be weak, may he come to the table of the Lord?
A. This Sacrament is not for these that are perfect, but for to strengthen these that are weake.
Q. What should the communicant try of his love?
A. If hee loveth his God better then all things.
Q. What should he try concerning his love towards his neighbour?
A. If he desireth by all meanes not only not to hurt, but also to his neighbour in his person, name, helpe and estate.

p.hi: Q. What shall he try of his repentance?

div.p: A. If hee from his heart bee sory for his bypast sins, and also bee resolved to amend his life in all times to come.

p.hi: Q. By what singes will this repentance appeare?

div.p: A. By seven

p.hi: Q. What is the first?

div.p: A. A care to leave the sinne wherein hee is fallen, 2 Cor. 7.11.

p.hi: Q. What is the second?

div.p: A. An utter condemnation of himselfe for sinne, with a craving pardon.
Q. What is the third?
A. A great anger against himselfe for his carelesnesse.
Q. What is the fourth?
A. A feare least hee should fall into the same sin againe.

p.hi: Q. What is the fifth?

div.p: A. A desire ever to please God.

p.hi: Q. What is the sixt?

div.p: A. A zeale, or increase of affection in well doing.
Q. What is the seventh?
A. Revenge upon himself for his former offence. 2 Cor. 7.11.

div.head: The fourtie two Sunday.
div.p: Q. THinkest thou that a man must have faith, love, and repentance, in a good measure before he come to the table of the Lord?
A. Yea, verily; for the wedding garment is made of these three graces.
Q. What then should be our chiefe exercise, before we come to the Lords Supper?
A. To try if we have faith love, and repentance.

p.hi: Q. What if wee want any of them?

div.p: A. Let us seek them from God by earnest prayer.

p.hi: Q. But may wee not come to the Sacrament without them?

div.p: A. No, not.
Q. What danger is if we come without them?
A. We eate and drinke judgement to our selves.
Q. Wherefore that?
A. Because we discerne not the Lords body.

div.head: The fourtie three Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat callest thou to discerne the Lords body?

div.p: A. It is to put a difference betweene the Sacramentall bread, the seale of his body, and other common bread.

p.hi: Q. What is the difference?

div.p: A. The bread of the Sacrament is given for to be a seale of the food of the soule; Other bread is but for the belly.

p.hi: Q. Let me understand more clearely who is said to discerne the Lords body?

div.p: A. He is truely said, to discerne the Lords body, who trembling in all reverence cometh to the table, and receaveth the bread, not as common bread for the belly, but as consecrate, for to be a seale of the spirituall food of the soule.

p.hi: Q. What is the punishment of these that communicate unworthily?

div.p: A. The punishment of the godly is sore sicknesse, great sorrowes, and sometimes death of body.
Q. What is the punishment of the wicked?
A. Death both of soule and body.
Q. Thinkest thou that the godly will whiles communicate unworthily?
A. Yea verily, and for that the Lord will fearfully chastise them in this life.

div.head: The fourtie foure Sunday.
div.p: Q. IS it not good for the godly, that they be so chastised for their negligence?
A. It is most certaine.

p.hi: Q. How knowest thou that?

div.p: A. The Apostle sayeth, when wee are judged wee are chastened of the Lord, that wee should not bee condemned with the World, 1 Cor. 11.32.

p.hi: Q. I see that there is great difference, betweene the unworthie communicating of the godly, and of the wicked?

div.p: A. Yea verily; for God chasteneth the godly for their negligence, but hee condemneth the wicked for their contempt.

p.hi: Q. But will not this make many of the godly the more carelesse in their preparation, seeing that though they communicate unworthily they shall not be condemned?

div.p:
A. The chastisement of their
negligence is to great that it should make the best of us to tremble, divers calamities as sicknesse, death, losse of goods, terrours of conscience are appointed for such.

div.head: The fourtie five Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat should we thinke upon, when we are come to the Lords table?

div.p: A. We should lift up our hearts to Christ in the heavens.
Qu. When thou seest the bread of the Sacrament broken, what should thou remember?
A. That even so the body of Christ was broken upon the crosse with unspeakable dolours for my sinnes.
Q. When thou seest the wine povvred out, vvhat shouldest thou remember?
A. That even so the blood of Christ was powred out upon the crosse for me.
Q. When thou eatest that bread of the Sacrament, what sayeth thou in thy self?
A. I say, Lord so feed my soule with Christs body, the bread of life.
Q. When thou drinkest the wine, what sayeth thou in thy selfe?
A. I say, Lord quench the thirst of my soule, with the vertue of Christs blood.

div.head: The fourtie sixth Sunday.
div.p: Q. DOE we eat with our teeth the flesh of Christs body at the Sacrament?
A. No, not.
Qu▪ How then eat we his body?
A. In a spirituall manner.
Q. How is that done?
A. While we believe; that his body was broken for us, we are said to eate his body.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore is our believing called a eating, and a drinking.

div.p: A. Because as our bodies live by eating and drinking, so our souls live by believing that Christs body was broken, and his blood powred out for our sins.

p.hi: Q. What is the chiefest end of this Sacrament?

div.p: A. That the Lords death may thankfully be remembered.

p.hi: Q. What is our duty after wee have received the Sacrament?

div.p: A. To give GOD most humble thankes.

p.hi: Q. How should we thanke him?

div.p: A. We must declare the Lords death untill he come againe.

p.hi: Q. What is that to declare the Lords death?

div.p: A It is to publish, to solemnize, to have in honour and estimation, to spread abroad, and make famous all the sufferings of the Lord.

div.head: The fourtie seven Sunday.

p.hi: Q. WHat more is required in our thankes, then to declare the Lords death by publishing the same by word?

div.p: A. It is required, that by a holy and reformed life wee glorifie God, that others seeing our godly conversation may praise our heavenly Father.

p.hi: Q. What wordes of thankes hast thou for God after thou hast received the Sacrament?

div.p: A. My soule praiseth God for his love, which moved him to send his Son to the world to die for me; I glorifie the Son of God, for dying so willingly for the salvation of my lost soule.

p.hi: Q. How concludest thou thy thanksgiving?

div.p: A. I say, now unto the King eternall, immortall, invisible, the only wise God, be glory, for ever, and ever, Amen. 1 Tim. 1 vers. 17.
Q. What is thy exercise the rest of that day?
A. I with a thankfull heart meditate the mercies of my God, who sent his Son to die for me, and by his death, to deliver me from hell fire.

p.hi: Q. What doest thou more?

div.p: A. I call to memorie all the paines and dolours, which Christ my Saviour suffered from his Cratch to the Crosse, and praise him for the same: To whom with the Father, and the holy Spirit the Comforter, be glory, power, and praise, for evermore, Amen.

div.head: TO THE NOBLE LADY, D. Anne Campbell; Daughter to the Noble and Potent Earle, the Earle of Argyle, &c.
div.p: I Heere humbly dedicate unto your Ladiship, now of tender yeeres these two compends of the Catechisme.

Saint Iohn, the Cusin, and beloved Disciple of Iesus Christ, who for his high doctrine was compared to an Eagle that mounteth very high, disdained not to write unto Children. In one chapter of a short Epistle hee hath▪ I write unto you little children;1 Joh. 2 12▪ vers. 13 and againe in the same words, I write unto you little children; of that his writing
hee giveth two reasons; the one is in these words, because your sins are forgiven you for his Names sake; the other reason is in these words, because yee have knowne the Father: For this end, Madame, have I written unto you these two compends, that yee may know the Father; whom I most humbly intreat to increase his graces begun in your Ladyship in a good measure▪

closer.signed: Your Ladiships most humble Servant, M. ZACHARY BOYD.

div.head: A short compend of the Catechisme, needfull for little Children.
I. OF GOD.
div.p: Question.

p.hi: HOW many Gods be there?
Answer.

div.p: Onely one God.

p.hi: Q. How many persones be there in the Godhead?

div.p: A. Three, the Father, the Son, and the holy Ghost.

p.hi: Q. What hath God the Father, done for thee?

div.p: A. He hath created me.
Q. What hath God the Son done for thee?
A. He hath redeemed me.
Q. What hath the holy Ghost done for thee?
A. He hath sanctified me.

div.head: Of Mans Creation.

p.hi: Q. WHereof was this world made?

div.p: A. Of nothing.
Q. Whereof was man made?
A. His body was made of the dust of the ground.
Q. How was his soule made?
A. The Lord breathed into his nosthrils the breath of life.

p.hi: Q. How was man created at the first?

div.p: A. According to Gods own image.
Q. What is that image of God?
A. Holinesse, and happinesse.

div.head: Of Mans Fall.
div.p: Q. DID man keepe that image?
A. No, not.
Q. How lost he it?
A. By sinning against God.
Q. What was his sinne?
A. He did eate of the forbidden tree.

p.hi: Q. What other sinnes did goe before that?

div.p: A. Pride, unbeliefe, a miscontentment with his own estate.
Q. What were the instruments of his fall?
A. The devill, the serpent, and the woman.
Q. How did they bring that evill to passe?
A. The devill entered into the serpent, and by the serpent seduced the woman, who entised her Husband to eate of that tree.
Q. What deserved they for that eating?
A. Death and eternall damnation.

p.hi: Q. What hath followed on that first sinne?

div.p: A. All men since that fall are borne in sin, and conceived in iniquitie.

p.hi: Q. What is sinne?

div.p: A. The transgression of Gods law.

p.hi: Q. How many sorts of sinne be there?

div.p: A. Two, originall sinne, and actuall sinne.

p.hi: Q. What callest thou originall sin?

div.p: A. That corruption wherein all mankinde is conceived and borne, since the fall of Adam.
Q. What is actuall sinne?
A. Every omission of our duty and commission of that which is against the law of God.

p.hi: Q. In how many wayes sinne wee against God?

div.p: A. In three wayes chiefly, in thought, word, and dead.

p.hi: Q. Are all men sinners?

div.p: A. Yea, verily, Christ onely excepted.

div.head: Of Mans Redemption.

p.hi: Q. WHO is mans Saviour?

div.p: A. Jesus Christ.

p.hi: Q. Who is this Iesus Christ?

div.p: A. The Son of God conceived miraculously by the holy Ghost, in the wombe of a Virgine.
Q. Whether was he man onely, or both God and man?
A. He was both God and man, in one person.
Q. What needed him to be man?
A. That he might die for us.

p.hi: Q. What needed him to be God?

div.p: A. That he might overcome death.

p.hi: Q. VVherefore was he called Iesus?

div.p: A. Because he came to save his people from their sinnes.

p.hi: Q. VVherefore callest thou him Christ?

div.p: A. Because he was annointed with the spirituall oyle of graces, and that without measure.

p.hi: Q. Whereunto was he annointed?

div.p: A. Unto three spirituall offices.

p.hi: Q. What were his offices?

div.p: A. He was a King, a Priest, and a Prophet.

p.hi: Q. What needed him to bee a King?

div.p: A. For to rule and defend us, against our enemies.

p.hi: Q. Who are our cheefest enemies?

div.p: A. The devill, the world, and the corruptions of our own flesh.
Q. What needed him to bee a Prophet?
A. For to teach us the Word, and way of Salvation.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore was hee a Priest?

div.p: A. That he might offer up a sacrifice for us.

p.hi: Q. What sacrifice offered he up for us?

div.p: A. He offered up himselfe to the death.

p.hi: Q. What sort of death died he for us?

div.p: A. The cursed death of the Crosse.
Q. Wherefore died he such a cursed death?
A. That hee might deliver us from the curse of God.

div.head: Of the service which man owe to God for his redemption.

p.hi: Q. WHat owe we to God for so great a salvation?

div.p: A. We owe him service.

p.hi: Q. How many parts are there of Gods service▪

div.p: A. Foure: viz. to believe in GOD, to obey GOD, to pray to GOD, and to give him thanks.

div.head: The first part of GODS Service.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the first part of Gods Service?

div.p: A. It is to believe in GOD.

p.hi: Q. What is that to believe in GOD?

div.p: A. It is to have a true faith.

p.hi: Q. What is faith?

div.p: A. An assured knowledge that GOD will be mercifull to us for Christs sake.

p.hi: Q. Who worketh this faith in our hearts?

div.p: A. The holy Spirit.

p.hi: Q. By what meanes?

div.p: A. By the preaching of the Word.
Q. VVhy are we said to be justified by faith?
A. Because by faith we apprehend Christ and all his merits; whereby we appeare just in Gods presence.

p.hi: Q. May not man be justified by his workes?

div.p: A. He may before men, but not before GOD.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is the cause of that?

div.p: A. Because there is no man that can perfectly fulfill the law of GOD.
Q. VVhere is the summe of our faith?
A. In the Creede.
Q. How many parts are there of the Creede?
A. Foure.
Q. VVhat is in the first part thereof?
A. That which concerneth GOD the Father, and our creation.
Q. VVhat is the second part?
A. That which concerneth God the Son and our redemption.
Q. What is in the third part?
A. That which concerneth GOD the holy Ghost, and our sanctification.
Q. What is in the fourth part?
A. That which concerneth the Church, and Gods benefites bestowed upon the same.
Q. What is the Church?
A. A companie of those, whom GOD by his Spirit hath sanctified.

p.hi: Q. How many parts hath the Church?

div.p: A. Two; the Church triumphant in Heaven, and the Church militant on Earth.

p.hi: Q. VVhom callest thou the Church triumphant?

div.p: A. These who have overcome the divel, the world, and the flesh.

p.hi: Q. VVhom callest thou the Church militant?

div.p: A. These who are yet on earth fighting against these enemies of mans salvation.

div.head: The second part of Gods Service?

p.hi: Q. WHat is the second part of Gods service?

div.p: A. To obey GOD ▪
Q. Where learnest thou what obedience thou owe to God?
A. In GODS Law, whereof the summe are the ten commandements.

p.hi: Q. How are the ten commandements divided?

div.p: A. Into two tables.
Q. What commandements be contained in the first table?
A. The first foure.

p.hi: Q. What be contained in the second table?

div.p: A. The last six.

p.hi: Q. What is the summe of the first foure?

div.p: A. Our whole duety towards our God.

p.hi: Q. What is the summe of the last six?

div.p: A. Our whole duety towards our neighbour.

div.head: The third part of Gods Service.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the third part of Gods service?

div.p: A. To pray to GOD.

p.hi: Q. In whose name must we seeke from God that which we need?

div.p: A. In Christ his Sons name.

p.hi: Q. May we desire the Saints in heaven, to interceede for us?

div.p: A. There is but one Mediator Jesus Christ.
Q. Who teacheth us to pray?
A. The holy Spirit.
Q. What prayer is most perfect?
A. The Lords prayer.

p.hi: Q. How many petitions are there in the Lords prayer?

div.p: A. Six.

p.hi: Q. What is the first?

div.p: A. Hallowed be thy name.
Q. What is that to say?
A. That God by all creatures, may be known to be a holy God, and worshipped by them.

p.hi: Q. What is the second petition?

div.p: A. Thy kingdome come.

p.hi: Q. What is that to say?

div.p: A. That God both outwardly▪ and inwardly rule, governe, and maintaine us, as a King his Subjects.

p.hi: Q. What is the third petition?

div.p: A. Thy will be done, in earth as it is in heaven.
Q. What is that to say?
A. It is a prayer, that God be as perfectly obeyed by his Saints on earth, as by these that are in heaven.
Q. What is the fourth petition?
A. Give us this day our dayly bread.
Q. Wat is that to say?
A. That GOD would give unto us any worldly thing that is needfull for us.
Q. What is the fifth petition?
A. Forgive us our sinnes, as we forgive these that sinne against us.

p.hi: Q. What understandest thou by these wordes?

div.p: A. That GOD in his mercy, would freely pardon us our sins, for Christs sake.
Q. What is the last petition?
A. And lead us not into temptation; but deliver us from evill.

p.hi: Q. What is the meaning thereof?

div.p: A. That God would deliver us from the snares of the Devill, of the world, and our owne corruptions, and from all other dangers whatsoever.

div.head: The fourth part of Gods Service.

p.hi: Q. WHat is the fourth part of Gods service?

div.p: A. To give God thanks for all his benefites.

p.hi: Q. What thankes requireth God of us?

div.p: A. That we set foorth his glory, with heart, tongue and hand.

p.hi: Q. How thanke we God with our heart?

div.p: A. When wee thinke honourably of him, and acknowledge his goodnesse.
Q. How thanke we him with the tongue?
A. When our tongue is an instrument of setting foorth his glory.

p.hi: Q. How thanke we him with the hand?

div.p: A. When we do good works.

div.head: Of the Sacraments.

p.hi: Q. WHAT is a Sacrament?

div.p: A. It is an outward seale appointed by GOD, for to certifie us of our Salvation in Christ Jesus.

p.hi: Q. How many Sacraments are there?

div.p: A. Two, Baptisme, and the Lords Supper.

div.head: Of Baptisme.

p.hi: Q. WHat is Baptisme?

div.p: A. A seale of our entrance into the Church.
Q. VVhat is the visible signe in Baptisme?
A. The element of water with the outward actions.

p.hi: Q. VVhat doth the water represent unto us?

div.p: A. The blood of Christ and the Spirit.

p.hi: Q. VVhat are the outward actions?

div.p: A. Sprinkling, washing, dipping into the water, abiding under the water, and comming out of the water.

p.hi: Q. VVhat spirituall graces are sealed up unto us, while wee are baptized?

div.p: A. Our justification and sanctification.

p.hi: Q What outward action represents our justification?

div.p: A. As the water washeth away all uncleanesse from the body, so the blood of Christ washeth away all sins from our soules, which is our justification.

p.hi: Q. What outward actions represent our Sanctification?

div.p:
A. They be especially three, first, the dipping of the body, secondly, the staying under the
water, thirdly, the comming out of the water.

p.hi: Q. What signifieth the dipping of the body.

div.p: A. It signifieth the mortification of sinne, or fellowship with Christ in his death.
Qu. VVhat signifieth the staying under the water?
A. It signifieth the buriall of sin.
Q. VVhat signifieth the coming out of the water?
A. The resurrection from sin to newnesse of life. Rom. 6.3. 4.

div.head: Of the Lords Supper.
div.p: Q. WHAT is the Lords Supper?
A. A seale of our spirituall nourishment in the Church.
Qu. What are the visible signes of that Sacrament?
A. Bread and wine with the outward actions.
Q. What doth the bread represent?
A. The body of Christ.
Q. What doth the breaking of the bread represent?
A. The great sorrowes wherewith his body and soule were broken.

p.hi: Q. What doth the wine signifie?

div.p: A. The blood of Christ.

p.hi: Q. What doth the powreing out of the wine signifie?

div.p: A. The powreing out of Christs blood.

p.hi: Q. What is the spirituall grace signified and offered unto us, by the elements and actions?

div.p: A. The spirituall nourishment of our soules.
Q. What must wee doe before wee come to the Sacrament?
A. We must try and examine our selves.
Q. Wherein consists that examination?
A. That a man try himselfe, if hee hath these three things, faith, love and repentance.
Q. What should hee try of his faith?
A. If he know God, and is in some measure assured that Christ died for him.

p.hi: Q. What should he try of his love?

div.p: A. If he loveth his GOD above all things; and if he loveth the well of his neighbours person, name, and estate.
Q. What shall he try of his repentance?
A. If from his heart hee bee sorry for his bypast sins, and resolved to amend his life for all times to come.
Q. May we not communicate without any of these three?
A. No, not.

p.hi: Q. What is the danger if wee want any of them?

div.p: A. Wee eat and drink judgement to our selves.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore that?

div.p: A. Because we discerne not the Lords body.
Q. What callest thou to discerne the Lords body?
A. It is to put a difference betweene the bread of the Sacrament, the seale of his Body, and other common bread?

p.hi: Q. What is that difference?

div.p: A. The bread of the Sacrament is given for to be a seale of the foode of the soule, other bread is but for the belly.

p.hi: Q. Who then is said rightly to discerne the Lords body?

div.p: A. He who in all reverence, trembling, receiveth the bread, not as common bread, but as consecrate, to be a seale of the food of the soule.

p.hi: Q. What is the punishment of those that communicate unworthily?

div.p: A. The punishment of the godly is fore sicknesse, great sorrowes, shame and disgrace, and sometimes death of body.

p.hi: Q. What is the punishment of the wicked?

div.p: A. Death both of soule and body; from which the Lord deliver us for Christ his Son sake.

div.head: A short Compend of the Catechisme for Children of a younger age.
I. OF GOD.
div.p: Question.

p.hi: HOW many Gods bee there?
Answere.

div.p: Onely one God.
Q. How many persones are there in the Godhead?
A. Three, the Father, Son, and holy Ghost.
Q. What hath the Father done for thee?
A. He hath created me.

p.hi: Q. What hath the Sonne done for thee?

div.p: A. He hath redeemed me.
Q. What hath the holy Ghost done for thee?
A. He hath sanctified me.

div.head: Of Mans Creation.

p.hi: Q. WHO made man?

div.p: A. GOD?
Q. Whereof was man made?
A. His body was made of the earth.
Q. How was his soule made?
A. The Lord breathed into his nosthrils the breath of life.

p.hi: Q. How was man created at the first?

div.p: A. According to Gods own image.
Q. What is that image of God?
A. Holinesse and righteousnesse, and dominion over all the creatures.

div.head: Of Mans Fall.
div.p: Q. DID man keepe that image?
A. No, not.
Q. How lost he it?
A. By eating of the forbidden tree.

p.hi: Q. What were the instruments of his sinne?

div.p: A. The Devill, the Serpent, and the Woman.

p.hi: Q. How did they bring that evill to passe?

div.p: A. The Devil entered into the Serpent, who deceived the Woman, and shee entised her Husband.
Q. VVhat deserved they for their sinne?
A. Death and damnation.
Q. VVhat is sinne?
A. The transgression of Gods Law.

p.hi: Q. How many sortes of sinne be there?

div.p: A. Two, originall sinne, and actuall sinne.

p.hi: Q. What is originall sinne?

div.p: A. That naturall corruption wherein we are borne.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is actuall sinne?

div.p: A. The evill which wee doe our selves, in thought, word and dead.

div.head: Of Mans Redemption.

p.hi: Q. WHO is mans Saviour?

div.p: A. Christ Jesus.

p.hi: Q. VVho is Iesus Christ?

div.p: A. Very GOD and man.
Q. VVhat needed him to be man?
A. That he might die for us.

p.hi: Q. VVhat needed him to be God?

div.p: A. That he might overcome death.

p.hi: Q. VVhat sort of death died he?

div.p: A. The cursed death of the Crosse.
Q. Wherefore died hee such a cursed death?
A. That he might deliver us from the curse of GOD.

p.hi: Q. How many offices had Christ?

div.p: A. Three, he was a King, a Priest, and a Prophet.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore was he a King?

div.p: A. For to rule us.
Q. Wherefore was he a Priest?
A. For to offer up himself in a Sacrifice for us.

p.hi: Q. Wherefore was he a Prophet?

div.p: A. For to teach us.

div.head: Of the Service we owe in GOD

p.hi: Q. HOW many parts are there of Gods service?

div.p: A. Foure; to believe in God, to obey God, to pray to God, and to give God thankes.
Q. What is faith?
A. It is an assured knowledge, that God will be mercifull to us, for Christs sake.
Q. Who worketh this faith in our hearts?
A. The holy Spirit.

p.hi: Q. By what meanes?

div.p: A. By the preaching of the Word.

p.hi: Q. How is our faith made stronger?

div.p: A. By the hearing of the word, and receiving of the Sacraments.

div.head: Of the Sacraments.

p.hi: Q. WHAT is a Sacrament?

div.p: A. It is an outward seale appointed by God, for to certifie us of our Salvation in Christ.
Q. How many Sacraments are there?
A. Two, Baptisme, and the Lords Supper.
Q. What is Baptisme?
A. A seale of our entrance into the Church.
Q. What is signified by the washing made by water?
A. The washing away of our sins by Christs bloud.

p.hi: Q. What is the Lords Supper?

div.p: A. A seale of our spirituall nourishment in the Church.
Q. What signifieth the breaking of the bread?
A. The breaking of Christs body with many sorrowes.

p.hi: Q. What signifieth the powreing out of the wine?

div.p: A. The powreing out of Christs blood upon the Crosse.

p.hi: Q. Who are worthy communicants?

div.p: A. God accounts these worthy, who have faith, love, and repentance.

div.head: A prayer at the houre of Death.
div.p: Because death is very uncertaine; and Pastors can not be ever pre sent at the last houre of dying men, I have set down this Prayer for the com fort of such,

MOST gracious GOD, most dear and loving Father, let the words of our mouth, and the meditations of our heart,Psal. 19.14 be acceptable in thy sight, for thou art our Lord, our strength and our Redeemer: We most unworthie to speake for our selves, are hold heere to call upon thee, and most humbly to intreate thee, to be gracious and mercifull to this thy faithfull servant, now going from the earth to his long home in the heavens.Eccles. 12.5

Thou Lord Jesus, who can not lie, hast said unto us:Iohn 14.13. That whatsoever
we shall aske the Father in thy name, thou wilt give it unto us; O Father of mercies, we seeke from thee, in the name of thy Son Jesus, that all the sinnes of this thy now dying servant may be forgotten, and fully and freely forgiven him: though his sins have indeed beene red like Scarlet and Crimson, Isa. 1.8 let it please thee so to wash him with the vertue of the blood of Jesus, that his soule once polluted and defiled with sinne, may be made white like the woole▪ yea, whiter then the snow.

Thou Lord understandest the groanes of thine own Spirit; thou hast begun a good worke in him; now as thou dost with the yeere,Psal. 65.11. crowne it with thy goodnesse: seale up in his heart that peace which thou hast purchased with the blood of Christ Jesus, the Prince of peace; Assure him now of the rest of these joyes, whereof he in
his life hath had by thy grace a mercifull foretaste, in the very throes of death, & greatest throngs of temptations; uphold him with the hope of glory: Let his faith get a full victory over all the enemies of his salvation: Let the vertue of Christs Crosse crucifie the world unto him, and him unto the world; let the death of Jesus be the death of his sinnes, and the life of his soule. Say unto his soule, Bee of good comfort, all thy sinnes are forgiven thee.

Seeing while he is heere at home in the body, he is absent from the Lord, make thou him confident and willing rather to be absent from the body, that he may bee present with thee his Lord in the heavens, among the Angels and and spirits of just men, who are alwayes in thy presence, beholding thy face, wherein is fulnesse of joy.

Now Lord, while his flesh and his heart faile him, be thou the strength of his heart, and his portion for ever; for whom hath he in heaven but thee, and there is none on earth whom hee desires besides thee: make haste Lord, come Lord, Jesus come. Open now the doores of thy mercy, and suffer this wearied traveller to enter into thine everlasting rest.

O Spirit of comforts, the Comforter of troubled soules, seale up in his heart the pardon of all sinnes, with the blood of Jesus, and now crowne all thy gifts and graces in him with thy glory, Lord Jesus receive his spirit, Father into thine hands wee commend his soule; To the Father, Son and holy Ghost, bee everlasting glory, praise, power and dominion, for ever, and ever, Amen.
